botanical_details.genus: Pelargonium can be perennials, sub-shrubs or shrubs, sometimes succulent and mostly evergreen, with palmately lobed or pinnately divided leaves and clusters of slightly irregular, 5-petalled flowers
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Angel pelargoniums are compact, bushy perennials with small, rounded leaves, sometimes scented, and clusters of small single flowers in shades of pink, red purple or white

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in containers of multipurpose compost in a greenhouse or conservatory, or on a well-lit windowsill. May stand outside after all risk of frost has passed, or use as bedding plants in fertile, neutral to alkaline soil in partial shade, then overwinter indoors as small plants grown from late-summer cuttings. See Pelargonium cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings, from spring to late summer
how_to_grow.pruning: Pinch out shoot tips in spring and early summer to encourage bushiness. Large plants overwintered indoors can be cut back hard in late autumn or early spring
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to vine weevil larvae (in pots), leafhopper, root mealybug and whitefly
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to grey moulds, a rust, viruses and leafy gall
